com.thunder.device

Class DeviceManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.thunder.device.DeviceManager

  • public class DeviceManager
extends java.lang.Object
    A useful class that provides data about the device, e.g. screen resolution or IMEI

      • getDisplaySize

        public static Point getDisplaySize(Context context)
        Gets the size of the display, in pixels.

        Note that this value should not be used for computing layouts, since a device will typically have screen decoration (such as a status bar) along the edges of the display that reduce the amount of application space available from the size returned here. Layouts should instead use the window size.

        The size is adjusted based on the current rotation of the display.

        The size returned by this method does not necessarily represent the actual raw size (native resolution) of the display. The returned size may be adjusted to exclude certain system decoration elements that are always visible. It may also be scaled to provide compatibility with older applications that were originally designed for smaller displays.

      • getDensityDpi

        public static int getDensityDpi(Context context)
        Parameters:
        context -
        Returns:
        The screen density expressed as dots-per-inch. May be either DisplayMetrics.DENSITY_LOW, DisplayMetrics.DENSITY_MEDIUM, or DisplayMetrics.DENSITY_HIGH.

      • getDensity

        public static float getDensity(Context context)
        Parameters:
        context -
        Returns:
        The logical density of the display. This is a scaling factor for the Density Independent Pixel unit, where one DIP is one pixel on an approximately 160 dpi screen (for example a 240x320, 1.5"x2" screen), providing the baseline of the system's display. Thus on a 160dpi screen this density value will be 1; on a 120 dpi screen it would be .75; etc.

        This value does not exactly follow the real screen size (as given by DisplayMetrics.xdpi and DisplayMetrics.ydpi, but rather is used to scale the size of the overall UI in steps based on gross changes in the display dpi. For example, a 240x320 screen will have a density of 1 even if its width is 1.8", 1.3", etc. However, if the screen resolution is increased to 320x480 but the screen size remained 1.5"x2" then the density would be increased (probably to 1.5).

      • getApiVersion

        public static int getApiVersion(Context context)
        The user-visible SDK version of the framework; its possible values are defined in Build.VERSION_CODES.

      • getDeviceName

        public static java.lang.String getDeviceName(Context context)

        The manufacturer of the product/hardware.

      • getMsisdn

        public static java.lang.String getMsisdn(Context context)
        Returns the phone number string for line 1, for example, the MSISDN for a GSM phone. Return null if it is unavailable.

      • getImei

        public static java.lang.String getImei(Context context)
        Returns the unique device ID, for example, the IMEI for GSM and the MEID or ESN for CDMA phones. Return null if device ID is not available.

        Requires Permission: READ_PHONE_STATE

      • getAndroidId

        public static java.lang.String getAndroidId(Context context)
        A 64-bit number (as a hex string) that is randomly generated when the user first sets up the device and should remain constant for the lifetime of the user's device. The value may change if a factory reset is performed on the device.

        Note: When a device has multiple users (available on certain devices running Android 4.2 or higher), each user appears as a completely separate device, so the ANDROID_ID value is unique to each user.

      • getImsi

        public static java.lang.String getImsi(Context context)
        Returns the unique subscriber ID, for example, the IMSI for a GSM phone. Return null if it is unavailable.

        Requires Permission: READ_PHONE_STATE
